Award.AwardTitle: 2012 CBET Grantee Conference, June 6-8, 2012, Baltimore, Maryland

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1250524
Kaunas

The NSF CBET Grantee Conference provides the opportunity for building more effective and collaborative relationships amongst the community of CBET grantees and Program Directors. The conference is designed to enable awardees to share their technical achievements with NSF Program Directors and also to learn about current (and/or new) NSF/CBET programs, practices, and supplemental funding mechanisms. CBET Program and Cluster-specific sessions will also facilitate discussions amongst these smaller communities to address topics of specific interest. The conference agenda will provide multiple outlets for networking and interaction with program officers and other grantees in efforts to promotediscussions and potential collaborations. The Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems (CBET) Division is amajor element of the Engineering (ENG) Directorate and critical to the Engineering Directorate'smission at the National Science Foundation (NSF). CBET's mission is to promote and supporttransformative research and education in engineering areas CBET's mission is to promote andsupport transformative research and education in engineering areas based on the physical, mathematical and life sciences; advance scientific and engineering knowledge; and develop a diverse, globally engaged workforce enhancing the economy of the United States.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI (grantee) attended the NSF CBET Grantee Conference (June 6-8, 2012) in Baltimore, MD and presented the results of his award ARRA award CBET 0854129 as a poster. The NSF CBET Grantee Conference provided the opportunity for build more effective and collaborative relationships amongst the community of CBET grantees and Program Directors. The PI shared his technical achievements with NSF Program Directors and also learned about  NSF/CBET programs, practices, and supplemental funding mechanisms. The PI also attended Cluster-specific sessions and participated in discussions.

The poster presented by the PI summzarized the integrated experimental and theoretical modeling studies that elucidated the mechanisms governing actin stress fiber reorganization in cells subjected to mechanical streching. Experiments demonstrated that cytoskeletal remodeling is response to cyclic stretch is dependent on the rate of strain applied. Theoretical modeling predicted that this strain rate dependence can be explained by the force-velocity relationship first described by A.V. Hill for muscle shortening. Briefly, stress fibers that undergo rapid lengthening and shortening, such as those oriented parallel to the stretching direction, cause rapid bond turnover events at actomyosin bonds, which in turn decreases the probability of binding. Subsequently, these stress fibers are more likely to dissociate and their assembly perpendicular to the direction of strain results in the most stable configuration.


Last Modified: 08/02/2013
Modified by: Roland R Kaunas
